    Highlights

    •
    The four types of CD3 signaling chains of TCR have functional diversity
    •
    CD3ε recruits Csk and p85 via its mono-phosphorylated ITAM and BRS motif respectively
    •
    Incorporation of CD3ε into 28Z CAR alters signaling to promote antitumor function
    •
    E28Z CAR-T cells have reduced cytokine production but enhanced persistence

    Summary

    A T cell receptor (TCR) mediates antigen-induced signaling through its associated CD3ε, δ, γ, and ζ, but the contributions of different CD3 chains remain elusive. Using quantitative mass spectrometry, we simultaneously quantitated the phosphorylation of the immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motif (ITAM) of all CD3 chains upon TCR stimulation. A subpopulation of CD3ε ITAMs was mono-phosphorylated, owing to Lck kinase selectivity, and specifically recruited the inhibitory Csk kinase to attenuate TCR signaling, suggesting that TCR is a self-restrained signaling machinery containing both activating and inhibitory motifs. Moreover, we found that incorporation of the CD3ε cytoplasmic domain into a second-generation chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) improved antitumor activity of CAR-T cells. Mechanistically, the Csk-recruiting ITAM of CD3ε reduced CAR-T cytokine production whereas the basic residue rich sequence (BRS) of CD3ε promoted CAR-T persistence via p85 recruitment. Collectively, CD3ε is a built-in multifunctional signal tuner, and increasing CD3 diversity represents a strategy to design next-generation CAR.

    Graphical Abstract

    Keywords

    1. T cell receptor
    2. TCR
    3. CAR-T therapy
    4. cancer
    5. cytokine release
    6. cell persistence
    7. quantitative mass spectrometry
    8. phosphorylation pattern
    9. ITAM
    10. Csk
    11. p85

    Introduction

    T cells can discriminate a minute amount of non-self antigens with precision from a sea of self-antigens and elicit specific adaptive immune response against invading pathogens or cancer cells (Glanville et al., 2017

Despite sharing the YxxL/Ix6-8YxxL/I motif, each CD3 ITAM has a distinctive sequence, suggesting a specific role might exist (Love and Hayes, 2010

    ). Eliminating ITAM diversity while keeping ITAM multiplicity severely impairs TCR function, indicating a qualitative nature of CD3 ITAM signaling (Bettini et al., 2017
    6.
    Bettini, M.L. ∙ Chou, P.C. ∙ Guy, C.S. ...

    ). CD3 ITAMs are mainly phosphorylated by Lck and dephosphorylated by CD45. Dual-phosphorylated CD3 ITAMs interact with the tandem SH2 domains of Zap70 with a low nanomolar affinity, thus releasing Zap70 from an autoinhibited conformation to activate downstream signaling cascade (Au-Yeung et al., 2018
    3.
    Au-Yeung, B.B. ∙ Shah, N.H. ∙ Shen, L. ...

    Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2018; 36:127-156

    37.

    PubMed
    Google Scholar

    51.
    Osman, N. ∙ Turner, H. ∙ Lucas, S. ...

    31.
    Guirado, M. ∙ de Aós, I. ∙ Orta, T. ...
    Phosphorylation of the N-terminal and C-terminal CD3-epsilon-ITAM tyrosines is differentially regulated in T cells
    Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2002; 291:574-581
    Crossref
    Scopus (10)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Similarly, the two tyrosines in CD3ζ ITAM1 were reported to be functionally different (Sunder-Plassmann et al., 1997
    60.
    Sunder-Plassmann, R. ∙ Lialios, F. ∙ Madsen, M. ...
    Functional analysis of immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motif (ITAM)-mediated signal transduction: the two YxxL segments within a single CD3zeta-ITAM are functionally distinct
    Eur. J. Immunol. 1997; 27:2001-2009
    Crossref
    Scopus (38)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).
    The functional diversity of ITAMs has been also demonstrated in the context of chimeric antigen receptors (CARs). All existing CAR constructs utilize CD3ζ cytoplasmic domain as a fixed module to deliver a major activation signal. The three CD3ζ ITAMs, however, have different contributions to the antitumor function of CAR-T cells (Feucht et al., 2019
    24.
    Feucht, J. ∙ Sun, J. ∙ Eyquem, J. ...
    Calibration of CAR activation potential directs alternative T cell fates and therapeutic potency
    Nat. Med. 2019; 25:82-88
    Crossref
    Scopus (332)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), reflecting the need for better understanding of ITAM signaling. Whether CD3ε, δ, or γ could also be utilized in CARs has not been extensively tested.
    In this study, we developed a quantitative mass spectrometry method to simultaneously measure phosphorylation dynamics of all TCR tyrosines. We stimulated TCR under various conditions to dissect the roles of Lck and CD45 in shaping ITAM phosphorylation patterns. A subpopulation of the CD3ε ITAM was found to be mono-phosphorylated under all conditions. We therefore determined the effector molecule recruited by CD3ε ITAM by biochemical and biophysical assays. Subsequently, we incorporated CD3ε cytoplasmic domain into 28Z CARs with different antigen specificity. CAR signaling and function were studied both in vitro and in vivo.

    Results

    Development of an Absolute Quantitative MS Method to Cover All CD3 ITAMs

    Phosphorylation of CD3 ITAMs has been detected in whole-cell lysate samples by mass spectrometry, but absolute quantitation is lacking (Goodfellow et al., 2015
    29.
    Goodfellow, H.S. ∙ Frushicheva, M.P. ∙ Ji, Q. ...
    The catalytic activity of the kinase ZAP-70 mediates basal signaling and negative feedback of the T cell receptor pathway
    Sci. Signal. 2015; 8:ra49
    Crossref
    Scopus (47)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Because of the large number of tyrosine sites in a TCR complex, it is technically challenging to simultaneously quantitate all phosphorylation sites with temporal resolution. Here, we developed a targeted-IP-multiplex-light-absolute-quantitative mass spectrometry (TIMLAQ-MS) method to enable absolute quantitation of all CD3 ITAM phosphorylation at different time points in a single measurement (Figure 1). Our method does not require usage of isotopic heavy-labeling peptides that are typically used in previous quantitative methods (Curran et al., 2015
    15.
    Curran, T.G. ∙ Zhang, Y. ∙ Ma, D.J. ...
    MARQUIS: a multiplex method for absolute quantification of peptides and posttranslational modifications
    Nat. Commun. 2015; 6:5924
    Crossref
    Scopus (37)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Gerber et al., 2003
    26.
    Gerber, S.A. ∙ Rush, J. ∙ Stemman, O. ...
    Absolute quantification of proteins and phosphoproteins from cell lysates by tandem MS
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2003; 100:6940-6945
    Crossref
    Scopus (1579)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Kirkpatrick et al., 2005
    40.
    Kirkpatrick, D.S. ∙ Gerber, S.A. ∙ Gygi, S.P.
    The absolute quantification strategy: a general procedure for the quantification of proteins and post-translational modifications
    Methods. 2005; 35:265-273
    Crossref
    Scopus (494)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In TIMLAQ-MS, six standard samples were mixed together with four analyte samples to serve as internal reference. To prepare the standard samples, synthesized phosphorylated/non-phosphorylated CD3 peptides of 6 different concentrations with a range of 330 folds (Table S1) were mixed with background proteins immunoprecipitated from unstimulated T cells by an IgG control antibody. The peptide concentration ranges were customized to generate a linear standard curve for each tyrosine site. To prepare the analyte samples of native TCR, α-hCD3ε (OKT3) was used to immunoprecipitate the TCR-CD3 complex from stimulated T cells at four different time points. A mild detergent digitonin was used to preserve the whole TCR-CD3 complex (Call et al., 2002
    9.
    Call, M.E. ∙ Pyrdol, J. ∙ Wiedmann, M. ...
    The organizing principle in the formation of the T cell receptor-CD3 complex
    Cell. 2002; 111:967-979
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (342)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Western blotting revealed that CD3δ/γ/ζ IP efficiencies were ∼50% and CD3ε IP efficiency was between 50% and 75%, which indicated that OKT3 immunoprecipitated not only the TCR-CD3 complex but also intracellular CD3ε that were not part of the complex (Figures S1A and S1B). Each of the standard and analyte samples was subjected to cysteine reduction and alkylation, trypsin digestion, and isobaric tandem mass tag (TMT) labeling processes (Figure 1A; Figures S1C and S1D), after which all samples were mixed and loaded to a TiO2 column for separation of phosphorylated and non-phosphorylated peptides. The methionine residues were further converted to methionine sulfoxide by H2O2 treatment to avoid interference caused by undesired modifications during the measurement (Figures S1E and S1F).
    Both data-dependent acquisition (DDA) and parallel reaction monitoring (PRM) liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) were implemented on a high-resolution mass spectrometer (Figure 1B). DDA was used to identify precursors containing different CD3 tyrosine sites at phosphorylated or non-phosphorylated state. The mass/charge value and retention time of each CD3 precursor were determined for targeted quantitation (Table S2). PRM was then performed to quantitate the identified target CD3 precursors. The intensity of TMT reporter carried by each CD3 precursor was measured for all standard and analyte samples. Linear standard curves with high coefficients of determination were generated for absolute quantitation of CD3 tyrosine phosphorylation level (pY/(pY+Y)) (Figure 1C).

    Phosphorylation Patterns of CD3 ITAMs

    TCR phosphorylation level is reciprocally controlled by Lck-mediated phosphorylation (Shah et al., 2018
    56.
    Shah, N.H. ∙ Löbel, M. ∙ Weiss, A. ...
    Fine-tuning of substrate preferences of the Src-family kinase Lck revealed through a high-throughput specificity screen
    eLife. 2018; 7:e35190
    Crossref
    Scopus (40)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and CD45-mediated dephosphorylation (Chang et al., 2016
    12.
    Chang, V.T. ∙ Fernandes, R.A. ∙ Ganzinger, K.A. ...
    Initiation of T cell signaling by CD45 segregation at ‘close contacts’
    Nat. Immunol. 2016; 17:574-582
    Crossref
    Scopus (206)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We therefore designed three stimulation conditions to dissect the roles of these two factors (Figures 2A–2C): a direct TCR activation condition, under which T cells were stimulated by (1) α-hCD3ε (OKT3) to study TCR phosphorylation under both Lck and CD45 regulations; (2) a phosphatase inhibition condition, under which T cells were stimulated by pervanadate, a pan phosphatase inhibitor, to study TCR phosphorylation under Lck regulation; and (3) a cell-free reconstituted TCR/Lck condition, under which CD3 chains and Lck were co-attached to large unilamellar vesicles (LUVs) to study Lck regulation in a well-defined membrane system (Figure S2) (Hui and Vale, 2014
    34.
    Hui, E. ∙ Vale, R.D.
    In vitro membrane reconstitution of the T-cell receptor proximal signaling network
    Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2014; 21:133-142
    Crossref
    Scopus (111)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). OKT3 was used at a non-saturating concentration to avoid high background noise and to mimic physiological condition under which antigen number is often limited.
    The tyrosine sites of all CD3 chains were faithfully quantified, except CD3δ-Y2 whose signal was interfered by background proteins under the direct TCR activation or phosphatase inhibition condition. CD3 phosphorylation induced by OKT3 was weaker than that by pervanadate, reflecting the weak binding affinity of OKT3 with CD3 heterodimer (Kjer-Nielsen et al., 2004
    41.
    Kjer-Nielsen, L. ∙ Dunstone, M.A. ∙ Kostenko, L. ...
    Crystal structure of the human T cell receptor CD3 epsilon gamma heterodimer complexed to the therapeutic mAb OKT3
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2004; 101:7675-7680
    Crossref
    Scopus (133)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In general, CD3 ITAM phosphorylation patterns were largely similar across the three foregoing conditions, indicating the dominant role of Lck regulation. The three ITAMs of CD3ζ, however, had condition-specific features. Under the direct TCR activation condition, the phosphorylation level of CD3ζ ITAM1 was higher than that of CD3ζ ITAM2/3. This difference was not observed under the phosphatase inhibition or the reconstituted TCR/Lck condition. This discrepancy suggested that CD45 might have a selectivity on the three CD3ζ ITAMs. Indeed, an on-membrane fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) experiment showed that CD45 dephosphorylated CD3ζ ITAM1 less efficiently than CD3ζ ITAM2 and 3, thus leading to higher CD3ζ ITAM1 phosphorylation levels when TCR was stimulated directly (Figure 2D).
    Among all CD3 ITAMs, CD3ε ITAM displayed a more evident mono-phosphorylation pattern under all three conditions (Figures 2A–2C). The membrane proximal tyrosine in CD3ε ITAM had a much higher phosphorylation level than the distal tyrosine, indicating that a significant subset of CD3ε was mono-phosphorylated at the proximal tyrosine. We further studied CD3ε phosphorylation under physiological antigen stimulation. Jurkat T cells were engineered to express tuberculosis (TB) antigen-specific TCR and stimulated by antigen-pulsed B cells (Glanville et al., 2017
    28.
    Glanville, J. ∙ Huang, H. ∙ Nau, A. ...
    Identifying specificity groups in the T cell receptor repertoire
    Nature. 2017; 547:94-98
    Crossref
    Scopus (632)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The same mono-phosphorylation pattern of CD3ε ITAM was observed (Figures 3A–3E). We then compared the phosphorylation kinetics of the proximal tyrosine (Y1) and distal tyrosine (Y2) of CD3ε ITAM with an on-membrane phosphorylation assay. CD3ε Y1 (the Y2F mutant) showed faster phosphorylation kinetics than CD3ε Y2 (the Y1F mutant) (Figures 3F–3H). A previous report showed that CD3ε basic residue rich sequence (BRS) had ionic interaction with Lck regulatory domains, and CD3ε proline rich sequence (PRS) reinforced such an interaction (Li et al., 2017
    43.
    Li, L. ∙ Guo, X. ∙ Shi, X. ...
    Ionic CD3-Lck interaction regulates the initiation of T-cell receptor signaling
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2017; 114:E5891-E5899
    Crossref
    Scopus (69)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Mutating BRS/PRS motifs clearly reduced phosphorylation levels of both CD3ε tyrosines and slowed down CD3ε Y1 phosphorylation to a rate similar to that of CD3ε Y2 (Figures 3F, 3I, and 3J). Thus, CD3ε BRS and PRS motifs appear to be essential for inducing the mono-phosphorylation pattern of CD3ε ITAM. Notably, the membrane proximal BRS/PRS motifs are present in CD3ε but absent in other CD3 chains. This might explain why CD3ε, but not other CD3 chains, displayed an evident mono-phosphorylation pattern.

    CD3ε ITAM Recruits the Inhibitory Kinase Csk

    It has been well documented that dual-phosphorylated CD3 ITAM interacts with Zap70 with high affinity (Au-Yeung et al., 2018
    3.
    Au-Yeung, B.B. ∙ Shah, N.H. ∙ Shen, L. ...
    ZAP-70 in Signaling, Biology, and Disease
    Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2018; 36:127-156
    Crossref
    Scopus (99)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) whereas mono-phosphorylated CD3 ITAM loses binding with Zap70 (Isakov et al., 1995
    37.
    Isakov, N. ∙ Wange, R.L. ∙ Burgess, W.H. ...
    ZAP-70 binding specificity to T cell receptor tyrosine-based activation motifs: the tandem SH2 domains of ZAP-70 bind distinct tyrosine-based activation motifs with varying affinity
    J. Exp. Med. 1995; 181:375-380
    Crossref
    Scopus (179)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In fact, mono-phosphorylated ITAM can be inhibitory as shown in the case of mono-phosphorylated Fc receptor ITAM that recruits Shp1 phosphatase to dephosphorylate other signaling molecules (Ben Mkaddem et al., 2019
    4.
    Ben Mkaddem, S. ∙ Benhamou, M. ∙ Monteiro, R.C.
    Understanding Fc Receptor Involvement in Inflammatory Diseases: From Mechanisms to New Therapeutic Tools
    Front. Immunol. 2019; 10:811
    Crossref
    Scopus (180)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We then asked which inhibitory molecule could be recruited by CD3ε-ITAM. Besides quantitation of ITAM phosphorylation, the MS measurements in Figure 2 also identified a panel of SH2-containing proteins that co-immunoprecipitated with TCR, including three inhibitory molecules Csk, Shp1, and Shp2 (Figure 4A; Figure S3A). A membrane-reconstituted FRET experiment showed that CD3ε directly bound to Csk but not Shp1/2 upon ATP-triggered, Lck-catalyzed phosphorylation (Figure 4B). The estimated Kd of CD3ε-Csk interaction was 1.6 μM, though the saturation point was not reached because of protein aggregation (Figures 4C and 4D). Furthermore, CD3ε with the proximal tyrosine mono-phosphorylated (designated as CD3ε pY1) pulled down a significantly higher amount of endogenous Csk from primary T cells than did non-phosphorylated CD3ε (designated as CD3ε-Y1Y2) (Figure 4E; Figure S3B). Mutating PRS did not have a clear effect on the Csk pull-down efficiency by CD3ε pY1. Mutating BRS enhanced the pull-down efficiency, suggesting that BRS might inhibit CD3ε-Csk interaction.
    We then studied the interaction between CD3ε and Csk-SH2 domain at atomic resolution by solution nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy (Figures 4F–4J; Figures S3C–S3G). CD3ε-Y1Y2 had little effect on Csk-SH2 amide resonance signals, whereas CD3ε-pY1 caused substantial changes (Figure 4G). We categorized the resonance signal changes to six patterns (I to VI) according to the changes of peak intensity and position of each Csk-SH2 residue (Figures 4H–4J). Categories I to VI represented low to high binding affinities. Non-phosphorylated CD3ε-Y1Y2 mainly caused changes within category I, indicating little to no binding with Csk. CD3ε-pY1 mainly caused changes within categories III–V. Mutating BRS or PRS did not affect CD3ε-pY1 binding with Csk-SH2 domain (Figures S3C–S3G). In comparison, phosphoprotein associated with glycosphingolipid-enriched microdomains (Pag), another Csk-interacting protein on the plasma membrane, mainly caused changes within category IV–VI (Figures S3H and S3I), suggesting a higher Csk affinity for Pag than that of CD3ε-pY1. However, Pag has much lower transcriptional levels than Csk in T cells (Figure S3J). Therefore, even if 100% of Pag is phosphorylated and recruits Csk, free Csk molecules would exist and are thus available to bind with CD3ε. According to the structure of the Csk-Pag complex (Tanaka et al., 2013
    63.
    Tanaka, H. ∙ Akagi, K. ∙ Oneyama, C. ...
    Identification of a new interaction mode between the Src homology 2 domain of C-terminal Src kinase (Csk) and Csk-binding protein/phosphoprotein associated with glycosphingolipid microdomains
    J. Biol. Chem. 2013; 288:15240-15254
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (8)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), Csk-SH2 domain has two canonical pockets to bind with pY and an aliphatic residue at pY +3 position. CD3ε-pY1 titration caused evident changes of the key residues in these two pockets (Figure 4J), likely because of interactions with the phosphorylated proximal tyrosine and the isoleucine at the +3 position in CD3ε ITAM.
    Csk is an inhibitory tyrosine kinase that is known to downregulate Lck activity through phosphorylating the inhibitory tyrosine Lck-Y505 (Davidson et al., 2016

    Incorporation of CD3ε into 28Z CAR Reduces Cytokine Production while Promoting Persistence

    CAR-T therapies are often associated with excessive cytokine release, which are typically not observed in TCR-mediated response. The existing CAR constructs only contain the activating CD3ζ chain to mediate antigen signaling. We hypothesized that incorporating the inhibitory CD3ε ITAM into CAR might decrease its cytokine toxicity. The clinically approved CD19.28Z CAR utilizes CD28 and CD3ζ cytoplasmic domains as signaling modules (Kochenderfer et al., 2010
    42.
    Kochenderfer, J.N. ∙ Wilson, W.H. ∙ Janik, J.E. ...
    Eradication of B-lineage cells and regression of lymphoma in a patient treated with autologous T cells genetically engineered to recognize CD19
    Blood. 2010; 116:4099-4102
    Crossref
    Scopus (1106)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We compared two design strategies: inserting the entire CD3ε cytoplasmic domain at the membrane proximal position (N-terminal to CD28, named CD19.E28Z; Figure 5A) or at the membrane distal position (C-terminal to CD3ζ, named CD19.28ZE; Figure S4A). Although CD19.28ZE had poor surface expression (Figure S4B), CD19.E28Z had comparable surface expression as CD19.28Z (Figure 5B). We thus chose the E28Z strategy.
    The CD19.E28Z CAR-T cells had a similar CD4/CD8 ratio as the CD19.28Z CAR-T cells (Figure 5C). However, the CD19.E28Z CAR-T cells produced significantly lower levels of cytokines upon antigen stimulation, including interleukin-2 (IL-2), interferon gamma (IFN-γ), and tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-α) (Figures 5D–5F). No constitutive cytokine release was observed with the CD19.E28Z CAR-T cells (Figures S4C and S4D). We also noticed that the CD19.E28Z CAR-T cells had a lower level of apoptosis and a higher proliferation rate than the CD19.28Z CAR-T cells after antigen stimulation, leading to a higher cell number of the CD19.E28Z CAR-T cells (Figures 5G–5I). No obvious exhaustion feature was observed with the CD19.E28Z CAR-T cells (Figures 5J and 5K). Moreover, cytotoxicity was not affected by CD3ε insertion (Figure 5L). Replacing CD3ε sequence by a flexible linker of similar size abolished the proliferation advantage brought by CD3ε insertion (Figures S4B, S4E, and S4F), supporting the notion that it was the CD3ε signaling motifs rather than a distancing effect that caused the phenotypic differences between CD19.E28Z CAR and CD19.28Z CAR. We next tested the in vivo antitumor function of CAR-T cells carrying the CD3ε module in a mouse-xenograft model of B cell lymphoma. The CD19.E28Z CAR T cells showed better antitumor function than the CD19.28Z CAR T cells in suppressing tumor growth and prolonging survival time (Figures 5M and 5N).
    We also tested whether the modulatory functions of CD3ε could be applied to other CARs. Mesothelin is a tumor antigen associated with multiple solid tumors such as mesothelioma and pancreatic and ovarian cancers (Morello et al., 2016
    49.
    Morello, A. ∙ Sadelain, M. ∙ Adusumilli, P.S.
    Mesothelin-Targeted CARs: Driving T Cells to Solid Tumors
    Cancer Discov. 2016; 6:133-146
    Crossref
    Scopus (353)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Mesothelin CAR-T cell therapy shows promising antitumor activity in patients with malignant pleural disease from mesothelioma. Incorporation of CD3ε into the mesothelin.28Z CAR did not alter the surface expression level of CAR or the CD4/CD8 ratio (Figures S5A–S5C). The mesothelin.E28Z CAR-T cells had reduced cytokine production, enhanced persistence, and augmented in vivo antitumor function, similar to the CD19.E28Z CAR-T cells (Figures S5D–S5J).

    CD3ε ITAM Downregulates Cytokine Production of CAR-T Cells

    We next studied the signaling basis of impaired cytokine production of the CD19.E28Z CAR-T cells. CD19.E28Z CAR had a brief increase in CD3ζ phosphorylation level upon CD19 stimulation followed by a rapid decay to nearly no phosphorylation level at 90 min (Figure 6A). In contrast, CD19.28Z CAR had a more sustained antigen-induced CD3ζ phosphorylation (Figure 6A). Consistent with reduced CD3ζ phosphorylation, CD19.E28Z CAR had reduced Zap70 and Plcγ1 phosphorylation (Figure 6A). CD19.E28Z CAR and CD19.28Z CAR displayed a similar kinetics of antigen-induced downregulation of surface level within 2 h (Figure 6B). This could not explain the faster decay of CD19.E28Z phosphorylation level. Echoing the above-mentioned biochemical and biophysical observations of CD3ε-Csk interaction (Figure 4), a colocalization imaging experiment and a co-immunoprecipitation experiment both showed that CD19.E28Z CAR had higher level of Csk recruitment than CD19.28Z CAR, and this effect was at least partially dependent on CD3ε ITAM (Figures 6C–6G; Videos S1 and S2). Given the inhibitory function of Csk in T cell proximal signaling, higher level of Csk recruitment by CD19.E28Z CAR could lead to impaired signaling of the CD3ζ/Zap70/Plcγ1 axis and the subsequent cytokine reduction (Au-Yeung et al., 2018
    3.
    Au-Yeung, B.B. ∙ Shah, N.H. ∙ Shen, L. ...
    ZAP-70 in Signaling, Biology, and Disease
    Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2018; 36:127-156
    Crossref
    Scopus (99)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).
    eyJraWQiOiI4ZjUxYWNhY2IzYjhiNjNlNzFlYmIzYWFmYTU5NmZmYyIsImFsZyI6IlJTMjU2In0.eyJzdWIiOiIwY2RhYzRhMGE3YzNmZDhmMDlmMzljOTU1NzMzZDBlMCIsImtpZCI6IjhmNTFhY2FjYjNiOGI2M2U3MWViYjNhYWZhNTk2ZmZjIiwiZXhwIjoxNzQ5NjA4OTUxfQ.OOBG1gCx74YbQVT9O5dVlxMC1AkeoKz7Ic9jyarunzYd6iteyyoVAMUto9-nJGwRGYywwWAs0VVkJGo7Z87HbgWd_epmbAXroyTw4ykWJ6zqaeaiSMH7QGh1-JmuTbVj31eF71yWp-ozN3ZkZr67SiovT2d1YniifslDzymfBBRPE1_Bti85pqol8-2hTvwM_2zh4j2Qv9ymA8nh73w0EpC-CtfrVZuLM-tpwr7v2mg9DNrJ_mBB377VV6cyQewSlQkdz-0pNR4OI2zcaEC3hKGSAqlT8Ek0IhIMCkz3Nob3z-O5z0Kr30p5FUCXEBkwsfWIw6-398nrPSmkShMrsg

    Video S2. TIRF Imaging of CD19.28Z-mGFP CAR and mCherry-Csk, Related to Figure 6
    CD3ε has other functional motifs in addition to ITAM, i.e., a membrane-proximal BRS and a PRS preceding the ITAM. We thus generated specific mutants of ITAM, BRS, and PRS to study their roles in cytokine regulation (Figure S6A). ITAM or PRS mutation did not affect CAR surface expression whereas BRS mutation, either alone or in combination with PRS mutation, reduced the surface expression of CAR (Figure 6H; Figure S6B), in agreement with the role of BRS in regulating TCR surface level (Deford-Watts et al., 2009
    19.
    Deford-Watts, L.M. ∙ Tassin, T.C. ∙ Becker, A.M. ...
    The cytoplasmic tail of the T cell receptor CD3 epsilon subunit contains a phospholipid-binding motif that regulates T cell functions
    J. Immunol. 2009; 183:1055-1064
    Crossref
    Scopus (67)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The CD4/CD8 ratio for each mutant was not altered significantly (Figure 6I; Figure S6C). The ITAM mutation largely rescued cytokine reduction induced by CD3ε insertion, whereas the BRS mutation, PRS mutation, or BRS/PRS double mutation caused even lower cytokine production (Figures 6J–6L; Figures S6D–S6F). Thus, Csk-recruiting ITAM is the major motif of CD3ε responsible for the downregulation of cytokine production in the CD19.E28Z CAR-T cells. Neither ITAM mutation nor BRS/PRS mutation affected cytotoxicity of CAR-T cells (Figure S6G), consistent with the negligible role of CD3ε incorporation in cytotoxicity (Figure 5L). On the other hand, the ITAM mutation did not abolish but rather reinforced the proliferation advantage of CD19.E28Z CAR-T cells, suggesting that other motif of CD3ε is responsible for upregulating persistence (Figures 6M–6O).

    CD3ε BRS Upregulates Persistence of CAR-T Cells

    It is documented that AKT plays a central role in regulating CAR-T persistence and antitumor function (Guedan et al., 2020
    30.
    Guedan, S. ∙ Madar, A. ∙ Casado-Medrano, V. ...
    Single residue in CD28-costimulated CAR-T cells limits long-term persistence and antitumor durability
    J. Clin. Invest. 2020; 130:3087-3097
    Crossref
    Scopus (112)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Sun et al., 2010
    59.
    Sun, J. ∙ Dotti, G. ∙ Huye, L.E. ...
    T cells expressing constitutively active Akt resist multiple tumor-associated inhibitory mechanisms
    Mol. Ther. 2010; 18:2006-2017
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (59)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Zhong et al., 2010
    69.
    Zhong, X.S. ∙ Matsushita, M. ∙ Plotkin, J. ...
    Chimeric antigen receptors combining 4-1BB and CD28 signaling domains augment PI3kinase/AKT/Bcl-XL activation and CD8+ T cell-mediated tumor eradication
    Mol. Ther. 2010; 18:413-420
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (427)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We found that CD19.E28Z CAR-T cells had higher activation levels of AKT (Figure 7A) and its downstream mTORC1 (shown by S6 phosphorylation, Figure 7B). PI3K is an upstream regulator of AKT, and CD28 can recruit p85, the regulatory subunit of PI3K, through the interaction between the phosphorylated YxxM motif of CD28 and the SH2 domain of p85. CD3ε was also reported to recruit p85 (de Aós et al., 1997
    18.
    de Aós, I. ∙ Metzger, M.H. ∙ Exley, M. ...
    Tyrosine phosphorylation of the CD3-epsilon subunit of the T cell antigen receptor mediates enhanced association with phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase in Jurkat T cells
    J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272:25310-25318
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (49)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We indeed observed that CD3ε incorporation led to more recruitment of p85 to CD19.E28Z CAR upon antigen stimulation, in a fashion independent of CD3ε ITAM (Figures 7C and 7D). Through analysis of p85 structure, we noticed that its N-terminal SH3 domain is highly enriched with acidic residues (Figures S7A and S7B). We speculated that the negatively charged p85 SH3 domain might electrostatically interact with the positively charged CD3ε BRS motif to enhance PI3K/AKT signaling induced by CAR activation. Consistent with this notion, NMR experiments showed that the p85 SH3 domain interacted with CD3ε, as evidenced by disturbances of p85-SH3 signals caused by CD3ε titration (Figures S7C–S7G). Unlike the interaction between CD3ε and Csk SH2 domain that was dependent on ITAM phosphorylation (Figures S3C–S3G), the interaction between CD3ε and p85 SH3 domain was dependent on BRS instead of ITAM phosphorylation. The PRS mutation also affected CD3ε binding with p85-SH3, though to a slightly lesser degree than the BRS mutation.
    To explicitly study the role of BRS in CAR signaling, we generated a CAR construct with only the CD3ε BRS motif inserted before the 28Z sequence (Figure S6A). Comparable surface level and CD4/CD8 ratio were observed for CD19.EBRS28Z and CD19.28Z CARs (Figures 7E and 7F). The CD19.EBRS28Z CAR-T cells had enhanced persistence while there was similar cytokine production when compared with the CD19.28Z CAR-T cells, suggesting that CD3ε BRS mainly regulated persistence but not cytokine production (Figures 7G–7L). As expected, CD19.EBRS28Z CAR-T cells had comparable AKT signaling as CD19.E28Z CAR-T cells (Figure 7M), echoing the role of BRS in p85 interaction (Figures S7C–S7G).

    Discussion

    CD3 Phosphorylation Patterns

    To precisely map out the dynamics of all tyrosine phosphorylation of TCR rather than relative fold changes, an absolute quantification method was developed in this study. There are several proteomics methods for obtaining absolute quantification information. The most common ones are AQUA and MARQUIS (Curran et al., 2015
    15.
    Curran, T.G. ∙ Zhang, Y. ∙ Ma, D.J. ...
    MARQUIS: a multiplex method for absolute quantification of peptides and posttranslational modifications
    Nat. Commun. 2015; 6:5924
    Crossref
    Scopus (37)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Gerber et al., 2003
    26.
    Gerber, S.A. ∙ Rush, J. ∙ Stemman, O. ...
    Absolute quantification of proteins and phosphoproteins from cell lysates by tandem MS
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2003; 100:6940-6945
    Crossref
    Scopus (1579)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Kirkpatrick et al., 2005
    40.
    Kirkpatrick, D.S. ∙ Gerber, S.A. ∙ Gygi, S.P.
    The absolute quantification strategy: a general procedure for the quantification of proteins and post-translational modifications
    Methods. 2005; 35:265-273
    Crossref
    Scopus (494)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). AQUA is originally derived from the isotope dilution approach in quantitative study of small molecules. A heavy-labeled synthetic peptide with a known amount is spiked into sample at the beginning of sample preparation procedure. The elution profiles of the corresponding endogenous and added standard peptides are used to calculate the quantification information. The major drawback is that its single point calibration might lack accuracy. MARQUIS is an improved method that incorporates the isobaric chemical labeling to create a multiple-point calibration curve for each target peptide. These two popular methods both make use of heavy isotope labeling for differentiation of endogenous and standard peptides. Inspired by AQUA and MARQUIS, we developed an alternative method that bypasses the costly synthetic peptides with isotope labeling. We took advantage of targeted immunoprecipitation, isobaric chemical labeling, DDA, and PRM to perform an absolute quantitation of phosphorylation of all CD3 ITAMs at different time points in a single measurement, using multiple-point calibration curves (Figure 1). The advantage of using non-heavy-labeled standard peptides, besides its cost-effectiveness, is to reduce the complexity of MS spectrum and errors during data acquisition, thus increasing the quantitation accuracy. Using this TIMLAQ-MS method, we were able to unravel phosphorylation patterns of CD3 ITAMs under different stimulation conditions.
    We observed constitutive phosphorylation for all CD3 chains, consistent with earlier studies (Goodfellow et al., 2015
    29.
    Goodfellow, H.S. ∙ Frushicheva, M.P. ∙ Ji, Q. ...

In the T cell/pervanadate and T cell/α-CD3 systems, we used anti-CD3ε (OKT3) to immunoprecipitate the TCR-CD3 complex, and OKT3 in principle could also pull down intracellular CD3ε molecules that are not part of the TCR complex. It is likely that these free CD3ε molecules could not be phosphorylated upon TCR activation because of the lack of Lck in the vicinity, thereby decreasing the observed extent of CD3ε phosphorylation in T cell samples. CD3ε BRS and PRS were shown to interact with the unique and SH3 domains of Lck to facilitate TCR phosphorylation (Li et al., 2017
    43.
    Li, L. ∙ Guo, X. ∙ Shi, X. ...

    The phosphorylation patterns of the three CD3ζ ITAMs have been studied in different types of T cells using various technologies.     Inhibitory Signaling of CD3ε ITAM Mediated by Csk Recruitment

    Modulation of AKT Signaling by CD3ε

    In addition to the inhibitory ITAM, CD3ε also contains BRS and PRS motifs. Truncation of CD3ε cytoplasmic domain, but not that of CD3δ and CD3γ, led to the blockade of early thymocyte maturation at DN3 stage (Brodeur et al., 2009
    8.

    In summary, we show that TCR is a self-restrained signaling machinery that contains both activating and inhibitory signaling modules embedded in diverse CD3 signaling subunits. Increasing CD3 diversity of CAR, i.e., incorporation of CD3ε cytoplasmic domain, yielded a CAR with improved signaling profile and tumor control (Figure 7N).

    Experimental Model and Subject Details

    Cell lines

    Jurkat (RRID: CVCL_0367) (male), Raji (RRID: CVCL_0511) (male), K562 (RRID: CVCL_0004) (female), and PANC-1 (RRID: CVCL_0480) (male) cell lines were cultured in complete RPMI 1640 medium containing 10% FBS and antibiotics (100 μg mL−1 streptomycin and 100 units mL−1 penicillin, GIBCO), HEK293-FT cells (primary embryonal human kidney) were cultured with complete DMEM medium containing 10% FBS and antibiotics. All cell lines were cultured at 37°C in an atmosphere of 5% CO2.

    Mice

    Six- to eight-week-old female mice were used. NOD-PrkdcscidIL2rgtm1/Bcgen (B-NDG) mice, equivalent to the NSG mice, were housed under SPF conditions at the Shanghai Institute of Biochemistry and Cell Biology. Animals were randomly allocated to experimental groups. All mice experiments were conducted under an approved IACUC protocol of SIBCB, Chinese Academy of Sciences.

    Method Details

    Preparation of MS sample of native TCR (see Figure 1A for schematic illustration)

    Analyte sample
    To detect TCR phosphorylation level under different stimulation conditions, Jurkat cells (1x108 cells/mL) were stimulated at 37°C by TCR crosslinking (10 μg/mL α-hCD3 (clone OKT3)) or phosphatase inhibitor pervanadate (10 μM) for the indicated time in RPMI 1640 medium. OKT3 was used at non-saturating concentration for the purpose of reducing background noise. Stimulation was terminated by adding ice-cold 2x lysis/IP buffer (1% digitonin, 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH7.4, 150 mM NaCl, 10 mM EDTA, 4 mM Na3VO4, 40 mM NaF and complete protease inhibitor cocktail (Sigma-Aldrich)). Cell lysis was performed at 4°C for 1 h. Total cell lysate was centrifuged at 14000 g for 10 min to remove insoluble materials. OKT3 (5 μg per mL lysate) was added for the pervanadate sample. Protein G-Sepharose beads (50 μL per mL lysate) was added into both the pervandate and α-hCD3 samples and the cell lysates were rotated for 12 h at 4°C. After immunoprecipitation, Protein G-Sepharose beads were washed one time with the lysis/IP buffer, and then eluted with the glycine buffer (0.2 M Glycine/ 0.5% NP40, pH2.2) at 37°C for 15 min. The elution was repeated three times. Proteins in the eluate were precipitated by trichloroacetic acid (Sigma-Aldrich). The protein pellet was washed 3 times with cold acetone and dried in a rotary vacuum dryer (Labconco).
    Standard sample
    Unstimulated Jurkat cells (1x108 cells/mL) were suspended in RPMI 1640 medium and lysed with ice-cold 2x lysis/IP buffer. Cell lysis was performed at 4°C for 1 h. Total cell lysate was centrifuged at 14000 g for 10 min to remove insoluble materials, and then incubated with an IgG antibody (5 μg per mL lysate) and Protein G-Sepharose beads (50 μL per mL lysate) for 12 h at 4°C. Protein elution and precipitation protocol was the same as above. Synthetic phosphorylated and non-phosphorylated CD3 peptides of 6 different concentrations (see Table S1) were mixed with background proteins immunoprecipitated by the IgG control antibody to generate six standard samples. From cell lysis to trichloroacetic acid precipitation, standard samples were handled simultaneously with analyte samples.
    Disulfide bond reduction and cysteine alkylation
    Each analyte or standard sample was solubilized in 60 μL 100 mM TEAB buffer. To reduce disulfide bond, 5 μL 200 mM TCEP was added and samples were incubated at 55°C for 1 h. 5 μL 375 mM iodoacetamide was then added to alkylate reduced cysteines. The alkylation reaction was performed at room temperature for 30 min, followed by acetone precipitation for overnight. Samples were then centrifuged at 8000 g for 10 min at 4°C to collect the pellet.
    Trypsin digestion and TMT labeling
    The pellets were resuspended with 60 μL 100 mM TEAB and digested with trypsin (from the TMT10plex Isobaric Mass Tag Labeling Kit, trypsin : total protein = 1 : 15) per sample at 37°C for 16 h. Then each sample was labeled with 20.5 μL TMT10plex Label Reagent. Reactions proceeded at room temperature for 1 h and then were quenched by the addition of 8 μL 5% hydroxylamine for 15 min at room temperature. Finally, ten samples were combined in another microcentrifuge tube at equal amounts and dried in a rotary vacuum dryer.
    TiO2-based phosphopeptide enrichment
    The phosphopeptide enrichment process was similar to previous work (Cantin et al., 2007
    10.
    Cantin, G.T. ∙ Shock, T.R. ∙ Park, S.K. ...
    Optimizing TiO2-based phosphopeptide enrichment for automated multidimensional liquid chromatography coupled to tandem mass spectrometry
    Anal. Chem. 2007; 79:4666-4673
    Crossref
    Scopus (127)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Kasil frits were prepared in 250-μm-i.d. undeactivated, fused-silica capillary. A TiO2 column was made by packing Titansphere into the capillary to column length of 8 cm. To equilibrate the column, it was washed with 300 μL Buffer A (20% acetonitrile, 2% formic acid). Then the combined TMT labeled sample (dissolved in 300 μL Buffer A) was loaded onto the column in pressure bomb and the flowthrough was collected. Then the column was washed with 300 μL Buffer B (80% acetonitrile, 2% formic acid) and the washed fraction was also collected. The above flowthrough was repeatedly loaded onto the column for three times to ensure complete binding. The phosphopeptides were eluted with 300 μL 250 mM NH4HCO3 (alkalified with NH4OH to pH9.0). Eluate was acidified with 2.5% formic acid (final concentration) and all flowthrough fractions were combined. Both eluate and flowthrough samples were dried in rotary vacuum dryer and dissolve in 0.1% formic acid. The flowthrough and washed fraction were used for quantifying non-phosphorylated CD3 peptides and the eluate was used for quantifying the phosphorylated ones.
    Methionine oxidation by H2O2 treatment
    Samples were oxidized by 0.5% H2O2 at room temperature for 30 min, dried in rotary vacuum dryer and resuspended in 0.1% formic acid.

    Preparation of MS sample of reconstituted TCR (see Figures S2A and S2B for schematic illustration)

    Analyte sample
    Large unilamellar vesicles with 100 nm diameter were prepared as previously described (Xu et al., 2008
    67.
    Xu, C. ∙ Gagnon, E. ∙ Call, M.E. ...
    Regulation of T cell receptor activation by dynamic membrane binding of the CD3epsilon cytoplasmic tyrosine-based motif
    Cell. 2008; 135:702-713
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (349)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). POPC (90%) and DGS-NTA-Ni (10%) were used for LUV preparation. His-tagged CD3γCD/CD3δCD/CD3εCD/CD3ζCD peptides (pre-mixed according to the physiological CD3 stoichiometry within the TCR complex (1:1:2:2)), and His-tagged Lck (Millipore) were incubated with LUVs for 1 h at room temperature for membrane coating. ATP was then added to initiate the reaction. The reaction volume was 100 μL, and the final concentrations of ingredients were: 0.5 μM His-CD3γCD and His-CD3δCD, 1 μM His-CD3εCD and His-CD3ζCD, 7.1 nM His-tagged Lck, 1 mM phospholipids, 65 mM HEPES (pH7.0), 5 mM MgCl2, 3 μM Na3VO4, 1.25 mM DTT, 150 mM KCl, 0.2 mM ATP. The TCR phosphorylation reactions were proceeded at 37°C for 0, 15, 60 and 120 min and terminated with 33 μL trichloroacetic acid to precipitate proteins. The pellets were then washed 3 times with cold acetone, and dried by rotary vacuum dryer.
    Standard sample
    Standard CD3 peptides of 6 different concentrations were mixed according to Table S1.
    Sample treatment
    Since there is no cysteine in synthetic CD3γCD/CD3δCD/CD3εCD/CD3ζCD peptides, disulfide bond reduction and cysteine alkylation were not performed. The samples were trypsin digested and TMT10plex labeled as described above. The TiO2-based phosphopeptide enrichment was not needed because of low amount of background proteins. The samples were treated with H2O2 to oxidize methionine as described above.

    Mass spectrometry measurements

    DDA analysis
    Peptides were separated with an UltiMate 3000 RSLC nano LC system (Thermo Fisher Scientific) and emitted into a Q-Exactive Plus tandem mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The samples were loaded on a trap column (Thermo Fisher Scientific, 75 μm × 2 cm, particle size 3 μm, pore size 100 Å, C18) with a flow rate of 2.5 μL/min of 0.1% formic acid for 60 min. Then the trap column was connected to an analytical C18 column (Waters, 75 μm × 100 mm, particle size 1.8 μm, pore size 100 Å). Solvent A was 0.1% formic acid in 1% acetonitrile, while solvent B was 0.1% formic acid in 80% acetonitrile. The peptides were separated with a flow rate of 300 nL/min using a solvent gradient of 1% to 30% B for 495 min, followed by a 60 min washing gradient.
    For DDA method, each full-scan mass spectrum was recorded in positive ion mode over a scan range of 300 to 1800 m/z, maximum injection time of 50 ms, AGC target of 3e6, and an isolation window of 2 m/z at the resolution of 70,000 at 200 m/z. The m/z values initiating the MS/MS scan were set on the dynamic exclusion list for 30 s and the top 20 most intense ions (charge state +2, +3, +4) were selected for HCD fragmentation (30% normalized collision energy) and MS/MS scans. The MS/MS acquisition was set at the maximum injection time of 500 ms, AGC target of 5e5 and an isolation window of 2 m/z at the resolution of 35,000 at 200 m/z.
    PRM analysis
    For PRM method, the LC-MS/MS instruments and chromatographic setups were identical to DDA method. The PRM scan mode was set at the maximum injection time of 500 ms, AGC target of 5e5 and an isolation window of 2 m/z at the resolution of 35,000 at 200 m/z. Then 30% normalized collision energy was set for HCD fragmentation. Targeted CD3 precursor transitions and their corresponding retention times were extracted from the previous DDA discovery run and put into the PRM method as an inclusion list (Table S2).
    Data processing and analysis
    Database searches were performed with the Proteome Discoverer 2.1 (Thermo Fisher Scientific) using the Sequest HT search engine. Raw data were searched against the Swissprot database using human taxonomy with 20407 entries. The following search parameters were used: five missed cleavages were allowed for trypsin, carbamidomethylation of cysteines (+57.021 Da) and TMT6plex modification of peptide N-terminal and lysine (+229.163 Da) were set as fixed modification, and the oxidation of methionine (+15.995 Da), the oxidation plus TMT6plex modification of methionine (+245.158 Da), the phosphorylation of tyrosine (+79.966 Da) were considered as variable modification. Precursor mass tolerance was set to ± 10 ppm and fragment mass tolerance was set to ± 0.05 Da. Target FDR was set to 1% as the filter cut-off for the high-confidence peptides and proteins.
    DDA and PRM data processing was performed within Skyline (v3.6). For absolute quantitation, peak area of each TMT reporter ion was exported. Standard curves were constructed by plotting peak areas of standard peptide against concentrations. Then the peak area of each pY and Y site was plugged into its corresponding standard curve to get the absolute value.
    P⁢h⁢o⁢s⁢p⁢h⁢o⁢r⁢y⁢l⁢a⁢t⁢i⁢o⁢nl⁢e⁢v⁢e⁢l:p=𝑚⁢𝑒⁢𝑎⁢𝑛 (𝑝⁢𝑌)𝑚⁢𝑒⁢𝑎⁢𝑛 (𝑝⁢𝑌)+𝑚⁢𝑒⁢𝑎⁢𝑛 (𝑌)
    A⁢b⁢s⁢o⁢l⁢u⁢t⁢ee⁢r⁢r⁢o⁢ro⁢fp⁢h⁢o⁢s⁢p⁢h⁢o⁢r⁢y⁢l⁢a⁢t⁢i⁢o⁢nl⁢e⁢v⁢e⁢l:A⁢E=(𝑆⁢𝐷 (𝑝⁢𝑌)𝑚⁢𝑒⁢𝑎⁢𝑛 (𝑝⁢𝑌)+𝑆⁢𝐷 (𝑝⁢𝑌)+𝑆⁢𝐷 (𝑌)𝑚⁢𝑒⁢𝑎⁢𝑛 (𝑝⁢𝑌)+𝑚⁢𝑒⁢𝑎⁢𝑛 (𝑌)) ⅹ 𝑃
    Quantification of TCR associated proteins
    Raw MS files were processed with MaxQuant software (v.1.6.2.10) for database search with the Andromeda search engine and quantitative analysis. Data were searched against Swissprot database using human taxonomy with 20407 entries. The following search parameters were used: two missed cleavages were allowed for trypsin, carbamidomethylation of cysteines (+57.021 Da) and TMT6plex modification of peptide N-terminal and lysine (+229.163 Da) were set as fixed modification, and the oxidation of methionine (+15.995 Da) and the acetyl of protein N-terminal were considered as variable modification. The precursor mass tolerance was set to 20 ppm for the first search and 4.5 ppm for the main Andromeda database search. The fragment mass tolerance was set to 0.05 Da. “Reporter ion MS2” was chosen for quantifying TMT labeling samples. Minimum peptide length was set to seven amino acids and target FDR was set to 1% as the filter cut-off for the identified peptides. Protein quantification was based on unique and razor peptides.

    CD3ε affinity pull down and mass spectrometry analysis

    CTL generation
    Splenocytes from OT-1 TCR transgenic mice were stimulated with 10 nM OVA peptide and cultured in complete RPMI 1640 medium containing 10% FBS, antibiotics, 0.05 mM 2-mercaptoethanol and IL-2 (10 ng/mL). After 48 h, cells were washed to remove OVA and cultured for another 72 h in the presence of IL-2 (10 ng/mL) before CD3ε pull down.
    CD3ε pull down
    OT1 CTL were resuspended in 1640 medium. 2x ice-cold lysis/IP buffer (2% Nonidet P-40, 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH7.4, 150 mM NaCl, 10 mM EDTA, 4 mM Na3VO4, 40 mM NaF and complete protease inhibitor cocktail (Sigma-Aldrich)) was added to lyse the cells. Cell lysis was performed at 4°C for 1 h. Total cell lysate was centrifuged at 14000 g for 10 min to remove insoluble materials. 100 μg biotinylated CD3ε Y1Y2, CD3ε pY1, CD3ε pY1 BRS-mut or CD3ε pY1 PRS-mut and streptavidin magnetic beads (60 μL per sample) were added to the CTL lysate (1.5 x 108 cell per sample) and incubated for 12 h at 4°C. After immunoprecipitation, streptavidin magnetic beads were washed three times with buffer containing half 1640 medium and half wash buffer (0.2% Nonidet P-40, 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH7.4, 150 mM NaCl, 10 mM EDTA, 4 mM Na3VO4, 40 mM NaF), and then eluted with the glycine buffer (0.2 M Glycine/ 0.5% NP40, pH2.2) at 37°C for 10 min. Proteins in the eluate were precipitated by trichloroacetic acid (Sigma-Aldrich). The protein pellet was washed 3 times with cold acetone and dried in a rotary vacuum dryer (Labconco).
    Mass spectrometry analysis
    Samples were analyzed on a hybrid trapped-ion-mobility-spectrometry-Time-of-Flight (timsTOF) mass spectrometer (Bruker, Germany). Reversed-phase chromatography with nanoflow was performed on a nanoElute LC system (Bruker, Germany). Peptides were separated within 120 min at a flow rate of 300 nL/min on a 25 cm x 75 μm column with a laser-pulled electrospray emitter packed with 1.9 μm ReproSil-Pur 120 C18-AQ particles. Mobile phases A and B were water and ACN with 0.1% formic acid. Gradient of buffer B was increased from 2 to 22% within 90 min, followed by an increase to 37% within 10 min and a further increase to 95% within another 10 min. This percentage of buffer B will last for 10 more min to the process end. The dual TIMS analyzer was operated at a fixed duty cycle close to 100% using equal accumulation and ramp times of 100 ms each and recorded mass spectra in the range from m/z 100 – 1700. The experiments were performed in PASEF mode with 10 PASEF scans per topN acquisition cycle. The precursors that reached a ‘target value’ of 20,000 a.u. were dynamically excluded for 0.4 min. The quadrupole isolation width was set to 2 Th for m/z < 700 and 3 Th for m/z > 700.
    Raw MS files acquired in DDA mode were searched by PEAKS software (version Online X). The digestion enzyme was set at “trypsin KR-C” and up to 2 missed cleavages. The precursor tolerance was limited to 20 ppm and the fragment tolerance was set as 0.05 Da. MS/MS spectra were searched against the Swissprot mouse database with 17,038 entries. Carbamidomethyl of cysteine residues and oxidation of methionine residues were defined as a fixed modification and a variable modifications, respectively. 1% FDR was applied at peptide-spectrum match (PSM) level. Label free Protein relative quantification (LFQ) is performed based on the extracted ion chromatograms of the whole isotopic envelope on MS1 level. Four-dimensional (m/z, retention time, ion-mobility, intensity) features of PASEF data were aligned between different mass runs.

    CAR-T experiments

    Design of CAR constructs
    Designs of different CAR constructs were displayed in Figures 5A, S4A, S5A, and S6A. pHAGE lentiviral vector was used for CAR expression. An eGFP-T2A cassette was included to monitor CAR expression level. The DNA sequences of FMC63 scFv, SS1 scFv, human CD28, CD3ε, and CD3ζ domains were from GenBank or previous studies (Carpenito et al., 2009

    ). In CD19 CAR constructs, FMC63 scFv was used for antigen recognition. In mesothelin CAR constructs, SS1 svFv was used for antigen recognition.
    Generation of CAR-T cells
    Human PBMCs were isolated from peripheral blood of healthy donors by density gradient centrifugation with the Lymphoprep reagent (StemCell Technologies #07801). PBMCs were resuspended at 1 × 106 cells/mL in complete OpTmizer T Cell Expansion SFM medium, supplemented with 5% Human AB serum, 10 mM neutralized NAC (Sigma-Aldrich #A9165), 100 U/mL penicillin/streptomycin, 2mM L-glutamine, and 10 ng/mL IL-7/IL-15. PBMCs were stimulated with the Human T-Activator CD3/CD28 Dynabeads (Life Technologies #11132D) for 24 h at a 1:1 bead:cell ratio. Then PBMCs were transduced with lentivirus for 24 h. At day4 after T cells stimulation, the Dynabeads were removed and CAR+ T cells were sorted with BD FACSAria III or BD FACSAria SORP for subsequent assays. After sorting and culture, the percentage of CD3+ T cells was up to 95%. CAR-T cells were cultured in normal complete medium in all experiments. CAR surface level and CD4/CD8 ratio were measured around 14 days after initial stimulation of PBMCs by CD3/CD28 Dynabeads.
    Cytokine production assay
    1x105 per well CD19 CAR-T cells were stimulated with Raji cells (CD19 positive) or K562 cells (CD19 negative) at a 1:1 ratio in a round bottom 96-well tissue culture plate for 24 h, in the presence of the Brefeldin A Solution (eBioscience, Catalog: 00-4506-51) for the last 4 h. Cytokine productions of CAR-T cells were measured by standard intracellular staining procedure with cytokine antibodies, such as APC Rat anti-human IL-2 (eBioscience, Cat#17-7029-82), BV421 Rat anti-human IL-2 (Biolegend, Cat#500328), APC mouse anti-human TNF-α (eBioscience, Cat#17-7349-82), PE mouse anti-human TNF-α (eBioscience, Cat# 12-7349-82), APC mouse anti-human IFN-γ (eBioscience, Cat#17-7319-82).
    For the Mesothelin CAR-T cells, K562 cells ectopically expressing mesothelin were used to provide antigen stimulation. Experimental procedure was the same for the CD19 CAR-T cells.
    CAR-T cell persistence assay
    CD19 CAR-T cells were stimulated with Raji cells at a 1:1 ratio. CAR-T cells were collected at different time points to calculate total CAR+ T cells number, detect Ki67 and Annexin V. Absolute number of CAR+ T cells (indicated by eGFP+) were counted by flow cytometry using the following formula: absolute number = (number of CAR+ T cells events per μL) x (total volume of suspension). Ki67 expression of CAR-T cells was measured according to the manufacturer’s instructions using a Foxp3/Transcription Factor Staining Buffer Set (eBioscience, Catalog: 00-5523-00) and APC mouse anti-human Ki67 (eBioscience, Catalog: 17-5699-42). CAR-T cells apoptosis were detected by an Annexin V Apoptosis Detection Kit APC (eBioscience, Catalog: 88-8007-74).
    For the Mesothelin CAR-T cells, K562 cells ectopically expressing mesothelin were used to provide antigen stimulation. Experimental procedure was the same for the CD19 CAR-T cells.
    CAR signaling
    For western blot detection of phosphorylated proteins, CAR-T cells and Raji cells were mixed at a 1:1 ratio, centrifuged at 500 g, 4°C for 2min to force interaction of the cells. Then cell mixture was incubated at 37°C to stimulate CAR-T cells and the reaction was stopped by adding equal volume cold 2x lysis buffer (4% NP40, 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH7.4, 150 mM NaCl, 10 mM EDTA, 4 mM Na3VO4, 40 mM NaF and complete protease inhibitor cocktail (Sigma-Aldrich)). Cell lysis was performed on ice for 30 min. Total cell lysate was centrifuged at 14000 g for 10 min to remove insoluble materials. The supernatant was subjected to SDS-PAGE and immunoblotted with the indicated antibodies.
    For flow cytometric analysis of phosphorylated proteins, CAR-T cells and Raji cells were suspended at completed RPMI 1640 medium plus 10% FBS, and prechilled on ice. CAR-T cells were mixed with Raji cells at a 1:1 ratio, centrifuged at 500 g, 4°C for 2min to force interaction of the cells. Then CAR-T cells were immediately stimulated at 37°C water bath for indicated time points and stopped by adding equal volume cold 8% PFA to fix for 10 min at room temperature. Fixed cells were permeabilized and blocked by PBS buffer with 0.1% Triton X-100 plus 2% BSA for 1 h at 4°C, then stained with primary antibody Rabbit anti-pAktSer473(4060, Cell Signaling Technology) or anti-pS6Ser235/236(2211, Cell Signaling Technology) for 1.5 h at 4°C, plus with secondary antibody goat anti-Rabbit IgG (H+L)-AF647(A-21245, Invitrogen) and PE-Cy7 mouse anti-human CD8 (Invitrogen, Cat# 25-0087-42). Antibodies were diluted at PBS buffer with 0.1% Triton X-100 plus 1% BSA. Cells were washed by PBS buffer with 0.1% Triton X-100 plus 0.5% BSA after each step of staining. Phosphorylated proteins level of CD8+ CAR-T cells were detected by flow cytometry.
    Cytotoxicity assay
    K562 cells ectopically expressed_CD19 and mCherry cells were used as target cells, and CD19- K562 cells labeled with CellTracker Deep Red Dye (Invitrogen, Cat#C34557) were used as non-target cells. The target and non-target cells were mixed at a 1:1 ratio and then co-incubated with CAR-T cells at a 3:1 or 1:1 or 1:3 effector : target ratio in a U-bottom 96 well plate. Cells were then centrifuged for 1 min at 400 g to induce cell interaction. After 24 h coculture, cells were resuspended and fixed with an equal volume of 2% PFA and kept on ice before flow cytometry analysis. Control samples contained only target and non-target cells to set a gate for live cells and another gate for a ratio of target to non-target. The gates were applied to all reaction samples. Cytotoxic activities of CAR-T cells were measured by calculating target/non-target ratio for each sample normalized by control samples. Flow cytometry was performed on an BD LSR II Flow cytometer and Beckman Coulter CytoFLEX Flow Cytometer.
    B cell lymphoma model
    Raji xenograft tumor was established by injecting 3 million Raji cells subcutaneously to the right flank of each mouse on day 0. After implantation, mice were randomly allocated into different experimental groups and injected intravenously 8 million CAR-T cells per mouse on day 6. Tumors were monitored by digital caliper and the tumor area was calculated as follows: (major axis of tumor) × (minor axis of tumor). Mice were euthanized when the tumor area reached 200 mm2.
    Pancreatic cancer model
    PANC-1 xenograft tumor was established by injecting 2 million PANC-1 cells subcutaneously to the right flank of each mouse on day 0. After implantation, mice were randomly allocated into different experimental groups and injected intravenously 6 million CAR-T cells per mouse on day 7. Tumors were monitored by digital caliper and the tumor area was calculated as follows: (major axis of tumor) × (minor axis of tumor). Mice were euthanized when the tumor area reached 200 mm2.

    Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy

    NMR experiments
    The NMR experiments for the backbone resonance assignment of Csk SH2 domain were performed at 298 K on Agilent DD2 600 MHz spectrometer equipped with a triple-resonance cryoprobe. The NMR sample contained 0.4 mM of uniformly 13C, 15N-labeled Csk SH2 domain in 20 mM phosphate buffer (pH 6.8), 50 mM NaCl and 10% D2O. In the 3D triple-resonance experiments, HNCO, HN(CA)CO, HNCACB, and CBCA(CO)NH were collected for backbone resonance assignment. Sequence-specific resonance assignments were made using the standard triple resonance techniques.
    To study CD3ε and Csk interaction, the titration experiments were performed on Agilent DD2 800 MHz spectrometer equipped with a triple-resonance cryoprobe using 15N-labeled Csk SH2 domain in the NMR buffer (100 mM sodium phosphate, 50 mM NaCl, pH 6.8) at 298 K. Non-phosphorylated CD3ε (CD3ε-Y1Y2), and mono-phosphorylated (CD3ε-pY1), non-phoshporyalted Pag, phoshporyalted Pag (Pag-pY317) were used for the titration experiments. [CD3ε]: [Csk-SH2] molar ratio was titrated up to 30:1 to reach saturation point. Side-by-side buffer titration was also performed to measure the dilution effect, which was minimal throughout the whole titration process. The concentration of the Csk SH2 domain was maintained at 0.1 or 0.05 mM. The amino acid sequences of the peptides are:
    CD3ε-Y1Y2: SKNRKAKAKPVTRGAGAGGRQRGQNKERPPPVPNPDYEPIRKGQRDLYSGLNQRRI
    CD3ε-pY1: SKNRKAKAKPVTRGAGAGGRQRGQNKERPPPVPNPD(pY)EPIRKGQRDLYSGLNQRRI
    Pag-Y317: TLTEEEISAMYSSVNKPGQLV
    Pag-pY317: TLTEEEISAM(pY)SSVNKPGQLV
    To investigate the role of BRS and PRS motifs in the interaction between CD3ε pY1 and Csk SH2 domain, titration experiments were performed on Agilent DD2 600 MHz spectrometer equipped with a triple-resonance cryoprobe using 15N-labeled Csk SH2 domain in the NMR buffer (100 mM phosphate buffer, 50 mM NaCl, pH 6.8) at 298 K and four kinds of CD3ε peptides: CD3ε-Y1Y2, CD3ε-pY1, CD3ε-pY1-BRS mut, and CD3ε-pY1-PRS mut. The four peptide sequences are shown in Figure S3B. The concentration of 15N-labeled Csk SH2 domain was maintained at 0.05 mM. The titration experiments were performed at two molar ratios (1:0 and 1:2) of Csk-SH2: CD3ε for each CD3ε peptide.
    To investigate the interaction between CD3ε and p85, titration experiments were performed on Bruker Avance 900 MHz spectrometer equipped with a triple-resonance cryoprobe using 15N-labeled p85 SH3 domain in the NMR buffer (50 mM potassium phosphate buffer, 100 mM KCl, pH 6.0) at 298 K and four kinds of CD3ε peptides: CD3ε-Y1Y2, CD3ε-pY1, CD3ε-pY1-BRS mut, and CD3ε-pY1-PRS mut. The concentration of 15N-labeled p85 SH3 domain was maintained at 0.1 mM. The titration experiments were performed at 1:1 molar ratio of p85-SH3:CD3ε for each CD3ε peptide.
    Categorization of signal perturbations caused by CD3ε titration
    In CD3 titration experiments, the signal perturbations of Csk are categorized to 6 (I to VI) types to represent low to high binding affinity, ranging from mM (Category II) to nM (Category VI). Category I represents no changes in both peak intensity and peak position; Category II represents changes in peak position but not in peak intensity; Category III represents changes in both peak position and peak intensity; Category IV represents disappearance of an “old” peak (peak broadening); Category V represents disappearance of an “old” peak coupled with gradual appearance of a “new” peak; Category VI represents disappearance of an “old” peak coupled with simultaneous appearance of a “new” peak.

    On-membrane FRET Assays
    Experiments were conducted as described (Hui and Vale, 2014
    34.
    Hui, E. ∙ Vale, R.D.
    In vitro membrane reconstitution of the T-cell receptor proximal signaling network
    Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2014; 21:133-142
    Crossref
    Scopus (111)
    PubMed

    ), with modifications. His-tagged proteins and non-His-tagged effector proteins were mixed at desired concentrations in reaction buffer (50 mM HEPES pH7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 10 mM MgCl2, 1 mM TCEP) containing 0.5 mg/mL BSA and LUVs with Rhodamine-PE. Reaction mixtures were aliquoted into a solid-white 384-well plate and incubated at room temperature for 40 min, during which the SC505 fluorescence intensity (F.I.) was continuously monitored to obtain the baseline. After incubation, 1 mM ATP (final concentration) was injected into each well to trigger phosphorylation, and the F.I. was further monitored. Data were normalized by setting the average F.I. value of the last 10 data points before ATP addition as 100% and the background fluorescence as 0%. In Figure 2D, indicated concentrations of CD45, 5 nM His-tagged Lck, 500 nM His-CD3ζ proteins, and 300 nM SC505-Zap70 were used. In Figures 4 and 1 μM CD3ε (Figure 4B) or indicated concentrations of CD3ε (Figure 4C), 10 nM His-tagged Lck, and 100 nM SC505-labeled SH2-containing proteins were used.
    For the CD45 dose-response curve, the extent of Zap70 recruitment at 30 min at 0 nM CD45 condition and no ATP condition were set as 100% and 0%, respectively, and the % recruitment at other CD45 concentrations was normalized to these conditions. Data were fitted with Prism 5.0 by using the “Dose-response-Inhibition,” yielding IC50 values.
    For the Csk binding curve, the drop of SC505 F.I. at 10 min were plotted as a function of CD3ε concentration. Data were fitted with Graphpad Prism 5.0 by using the “One site–specific binding,” yielding Kd value.
    On-membrane phosphorylation kinetic measurement
    1 μM CD3ε peptides were separately mixed with 20 nM Lck and 1 nM CD45 in reaction buffer (50 mM HEPES pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 10 mM MgCl2, 0.5 mg/mL BSA, 1 mM TCEP, and LUVs composed of 1 mM total lipids). The mixtures were incubated at 23°C for 40 min so that CD3ε, Lck, and CD45 bind onto LUVs via histidine-Ni-NTA interaction. After incubation, 1 mM ATP was added to the mixtures to start phosphorylation and the mixtures were further incubated at 23°C. At each time point after ATP addition indicated in the figures, portion of reaction mixtures were collected and mixed with SDS sample buffer to stop the reaction. The samples were heated at 95°C for 5 min, subjected to SDS-PAGE, and blotted by pY20 antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Cat#sc-1624). The optical densities (OD) of bands were quantified using ImageJ and normalized by setting the OD at 120 min as 100%. The t1/2 value under each condition was calculated by fitting the data to a standard sigmoidal curve by setting 0% and 100% as plateau in Graphpad Prism 5.

    T cell costimulatory receptor CD28 is a primary target for PD-1-mediated inhibition

    ). The CD19.28Z-CAR construct contains CD8 signal peptide, FMC63 scFv, CD8α hinge, CD28 transmembrane domain (CD28TM), CD28 cytoplasmic domain (CD28CD), CD3ζ cytoplasmic domain (CD3ζCD), and mGFP. The CD19.28Z-CAR construct contains additional CD3εCD between CD28TM and CD28CD. To produce lentiviruses, DNA coding the gene of interest was cloned into the pHR vector, and transfected to HEK293T cells together with the pMG2.G (envelop plasmid) psPAX2 (packaging plasmid) using polyethylenimine in DMEM. The medium was substituted with RPMI medium 24 h later and viruses were harvested another 48 h later. For gene transduction, 1 million Jurkat cells were resuspended in 1 mL fresh virus supernatant, incubated overnight at 37°C / 5% CO2.
    Supporting lipid bilayers (SLBs) were prepared as described (Hui et al., 2017
    35.
    Hui, E. ∙ Cheung, J. ∙ Zhu, J. ...
    T cell costimulatory receptor CD28 is a primary target for PD-1-mediated inhibition
    Science. 2017; 355:1428-1433
    Crossref
    Scopus (1135)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), and incubated with 5 nM CD19-His (Sino Biological) and 3 nM ICAM-1-His (Sino Biological) at 37°C for 1 h, followed by extensive wash to remove unbound proteins. CAR-mGFP/mCherry-Csk co-expressing Jurkat cells were plated onto SLBs functionalized with CD19 and ICAM-1. For live cell imaging shown in Videos S1, S2, time-lapse acquisition was immediately started after cell landing to the SLBs. For co-clustering analysis shown in Figure 6, cells were fixed using 4% paraformaldehyde in PBS 15 min after plating. After 10-min incubation at 37°C, cells were extensively washed with PBS containing 1 mg/mL BSA, and further incubated with PBS containing 0.1% Saponin and 1 mg/mL BSA for 10 min at 23°C. Cells were then washed with PBS containing 1 mg/mL BSA to remove Saponin and incubated for overnight at 4°C before TIRF microscopy observation. TIRF images were acquired at 37°C on a Nikon Eclipse Ti microscope equipped with a 100x Apo TIRF 1.49 NA objective, controlled by the Micro-Manager software (Edelstein et al., 2014
    23.
    Edelstein, A.D. ∙ Tsuchida, M.A. ∙ Amodaj, N. ...
    Advanced methods of microscope control using μManager software
    J. Biol. Methods. 2014; 1:e10
    Crossref
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and analyzed with ImageJ. The Pearson’s correlation coefficients were calculated using the “Coloc2” plugin in ImageJ with default settings after background signal subtraction using “Subtract background” command in ImageJ. Statistical significance was evaluated by two-tailed Student’s unpaired test in GraphPad Prism 5.

    Co-immunoprecipitation assay for CAR-T cells

    Jurkat cells were lentivirally transduced to express CAR-mGFP and cultured as described above. CAR-expressing Jurkat cells were serum starved at 37°C for 3 h to reduce the phosphorylation background. After the incubation, four million Jurkat cells were mixed with two million Raji B cells on ice. The cell mixture was centrifuged at 300 g for 1 min at 4°C to initiate the Jurkat-Raji contact and was immediately transferred into a 37°C water bath to start signaling in Jurkat cells. After the incubation, the cells were resuspended in lysis buffer (25 mM HEPES-NaOH, pH7.4, 150 mM NaCl, 1% NP-40, 5% Glycerol, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM PMSF, 10 mM Sodium Orthovanadate, 10 mM NaF) on ice, and centrifuged at 14000 g for 5 min to remove insoluble materials. The soluble cell lysate was mixed with GFP-Trap and incubated for 3 h at 4°C to immunoprecipitate mGFP-tagged CARs. After rinsed with wash buffer (10 mM HEPES-NaOH, pH7.4, 50 mM NaCl, 0.2% NP-40, 10 mM Sodium Orthovanadate, 10 mM NaF), the immunoprecipitated proteins were eluted with SDS sample buffer, subjected to SDS-PAGE, and immunoblotted with the indicated antibodies.

    Quantification and Statistical Analysis

    Statistical analyses were performed using GraphPad Prism 8.0.2 (GraphPad Software). Statistical significance was set to p < 0.05 and represented as ∗p < 0.05, ∗∗p < 0.01, ∗∗∗p < 0.001, ∗∗∗∗p < 0.0001, as indicated in the figure legends.
    Data are mean with SD. Exact P values are provided in the figures.
    In Figure 3, a two-tailed unpaired Student’s t test was used in H and J.
    In Figure 4, a Sidak’s multiple comparisons test was used in E.
    In Figure 5, a two-tailed unpaired Student’s t test was used in D-F. A Sidak’s multiple comparisons test was used in G-H, J-L. A two-way ANOVA was used in I and M (P value represents CAR factor). A Log-rank (Mantel-Cox) was used in N.
    In Figure 6, a two-tailed unpaired Student’s t test was used in D, E and G, a Sidak’s multiple comparisons test was used in J-N. A two-way ANOVA was used in O (P value represents CAR factor).
    In Figure 7, a Sidak’s multiple comparisons test was used in A, B, G-K, M. A two-way ANOVA was used in L (P value represents CAR factor). A two-tailed unpaired Student’s t test was used in C, D.
    In Figure S4, a Sidak’s multiple comparisons test was used in F.
    In Figure S5, a two-tailed unpaired Student’s t test was used in D-F. A Sidak’s multiple comparisons test was used in G. A two-way ANOVA was used in H, J (P value represents CAR factor).
    In Figure S6, a Sidak’s multiple comparisons test was used in D-G.

    Manage Consent Preferences

    Strictly Necessary Cookies

    Always active

    These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

    Functional Cookies

    These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.

    Performance Cookies

    These cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site.

    Targeting Cookies

    These cookies may be set through our site by our advertising partners. They may be used by those companies to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant adverts on other sites. If you do not allow these cookies, you will experience less targeted advertising.
